questions.text: A person recently experienced grief due to a serious illness in his father. Which of the following describes the ocular psycho-sensory reflex in this person?

options.label: A
options.text: Initial rapid dilatation due to inhibition of constrictor tone

options.label: B
options.text: Second dilatation is rapid in onset

options.label: C
options.text: Initial constriction due to increased constrictor tone

options.label: D
options.text: Initial constriction followed by dilation

questions.correct_answer: B. Second dilatation is rapid in onset
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Second dilatation is rapid in onset Sensory stimulation causes first a rapid dilatation of the pupil due to augmentation of the dilator tone through the cervical sympathetic and then a second dilatation , rapid in onset but slow in disappearance, due to inhibition of the constrictor tone.

Highyeild:

Psychosensory reflexes are not seen in Newborns and are fully developed at 6 months of age.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A . The initial rapid dilatation is due to augmentation of the dilator tone through the cervical sympathetic. Options: C, D . There is no constriction in the psycho-sensory reflex

questions.text: A 46-year-old diabetic patient presents to Ophthalmology Opd for routine check-up. Fundoscopy is normal. The doctor checks for near reflexes. What forms the near reflex?

options.label: A
options.text: Convergence

options.label: B
options.text: Accommodation

options.label: C
options.text: Miosis

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above The near reflex is a combination of three effects— convergence, accommodation and miosis .

Highyeild:

It is initiated mainly by fibres from the medial rectus muscles which contract on convergence . From these muscles, afferent fibres run centrally, probably by the third nerve, to the mesencephalic nucleus of the fifth nerve, and to a presumptive convergence centre in the tectal or pretectal region.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options: A and C. From here the pathway is relayed to the Edinger-Westphal nucleus and along the third nerve to the sphincter muscle of the iris so that the pupil contracts (miosis) with convergence. Option: B .At the same time, accommodation reinforces the reflex by visual impulses relayed from the cortex to the Edinger-Westphal nucleus.

Extraedge:

Darkness reflex- From lighted to dim environment Physiology - Abolition of light reflex- relaxation of sphincter pupillae . Contraction of dilator pupillae.

questions.text: A patient presents to the Ophthalmology Opd with complaints of mild headache for 20 days. His vision is checked and is 6/12 in both eyes. Which of the following is incorrect regarding the visual pathway?

options.label: A
options.text: Bipolar cell is a neuron of the first order

options.label: B
options.text: Ganglion cell is a neuron of second order

options.label: C
options.text: Optic tract passes to the medial geniculate body

options.label: D
options.text: Both b and c

questions.correct_answer: C. Optic tract passes to the medial geniculate body
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Optic tract passes to the medial geniculate body The neurons of second order i.e. the ganglion cells pass into the nerve fibre layer to the lateral geniculate body , and not medial. Here the neuron of third order takes up the transmission of the impulse travels by way of the optic radiations to the cortex of the occipital lobe.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. The first conducting nerve cell or neuron of the first order is the bipolar cell of the inner nuclear layer of the retina, with its axon in the inner reticular layer. Option: B . The neurons of the second order are the ganglion cells in the retina, the processes of which pass into the nerve fibre layer to the lateral geniculate body.

questions.text: A patient presents with visual disturbances. He complains of left inferior quadrantanopia. Damage to which of the following structures leads to this defect?

options.label: A
options.text: Left parietal lobe optic radiation

options.label: B
options.text: Right parietal lobe optic radiation

options.label: C
options.text: Left temporal lobe optic radiation

options.label: D
options.text: Right temporal lobe optic radiation

questions.correct_answer: A. Left parietal lobe optic radiation
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Left parietal lobe optic radiation The optic radiation separates into two - the ventral fibres projecting the lower quadrant of the retina or the upper quadrant of the visual field enter the temporal lobe before they turn back to the lower portion of the visual cortex and the dorsal fibres projecting the upper retinal quadrant or lower quadrant of the visual field enters into the parietal lobe followed by upper part of the visual cortex. precuneus region (medial surface of the cerebral hemisphere)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B . Damage to right parietal lobe optic radiation would lead to right inferior quadrantanopia Options: C, D. Damage to temporal lobe optic radiation would lead to superior quadrantanopia of the same side.

questions.text: A patient presents with visual disturbances. He complains of a central scotoma. Which of the following is incorrect regarding the visual pathway?

options.label: A
options.text: Part of the occipital lobe above the calcarine fissure represents the lower quadrant of the retina

options.label: B
options.text: posterior part of the occipital lobe represents the macula

options.label: C
options.text: Part of the occipital lobe below the calcarine fissure represents the upper quadrant of the retina

options.label: D
options.text: Both A and C

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Both A and C This patient most likely has a central scotoma due to a lesion in the macula or posterior part of the occipital lobe which represents the macula. The occipital lobe has spatial arrangement -the parts above and below the calcarine fissure represent the upper and lower corresponding quadrants of both retinae, respectively.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B.The posterior part of the occipital lobe represents the macula.

questions.text: An 18-year-old patient presents with a headache for 20 days. His visual acuity in the right eye is 6/18 and in the left eye is 6/12. Reflexes are tested. Which of the following is incorrect regarding near reflex?

options.label: A
options.text: Convergence pathway is initiated by fibres from medial rectus muscles

options.label: B
options.text: Visual impulses are relayed from the cortex to the Edinger Westphal nucleus for accommodation

options.label: C
options.text: Near reflex includes mydriasis

options.label: D
options.text: Fibres from the mesencephalic nucleus of the fifth nerve pass to a convergence centre in the tectal or pretectal region.

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Near reflex includes mydriasis The near reflex is a combination of three effects i.e. convergence, accommodation and miosis, and not mydriasis.

Highyeild:

Darkness reflex- From lighted to dim environment Physiology - Abolition of light reflex- relaxation of sphincter pupillae . Contraction of dilator pupillae.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. The convergence pathway is initiated mainly by fibres from the medial rectus muscles which contract on convergence. Option: B .Along with convergence, accommodation reinforces the near reflex by visual impulses relayed from the cortex to the Edinger-Westphal nucleus. Option: D. Mesencephalic nucleus of the fifth nerve, to a presumptive convergence centre in the tectal or pretectal region. Light - Near Dissociation Bilateral complete afferent pathway defect The lesion in the midbrain at the level of the pretectal area CN lll palsy with the regeneration of MR innervation pathway Ciliary ganglion or short ciliary nerve with the regeneration of accommodation fibres into sphincter pupillae.

Extraedge:

Light - Near Dissociation Bilateral complete afferent pathway defect The lesion in the midbrain at the level of the pretectal area CN lll palsy with the regeneration of MR innervation pathway Ciliary ganglion or short ciliary nerve with the regeneration of accommodation fibres into sphincter pupillae.
